question: Question_11
statement:
\textbf{Full-Solution Problem. Justify your answer and show your work.
Full simplification of numerical answers is required unless explicitly
stated otherwise.}

Prove that there exists at most one positive real number
$\displaystyle x$ such that $\displaystyle 4^x = 3\cos x$.
sols:
First we observe that $\displaystyle 4^x$ and $\displaystyle 3 \cos x$
are both continuous on $\mathbb{R}$. It follows that
$\displaystyle f(x) = 4^x - 3\cos x$ is also continuous on $\mathbb{R}$.
Note that $f(x) = 0 \iff 4^x = 3 \cos x$. We must show that
$\displaystyle f(x)$ has at most one zero.

\textbf{Optional:} Show that a zero \emph{exists}.

Plugging in the values $\displaystyle f(0) = 4^0-3\cos(0) = 1-3 = -2$
and
$f\left(\frac{\pi}{2}\right) = 4^{\pi/2}-3\cos\left(\frac{\pi}{2}\right) = 4^{\pi/2}$
we see that $\displaystyle f(0) < 0 < f\left(\frac{\pi}{2}\right)$. Thus
by the Intermediate Value Theorem,
$\exists c \in \left(0, \frac{\pi}{2}\right): f(c) = 0.$ In particular,
this implies that this positive number \emph{c} satisfies
$\displaystyle 4^c = 3 \cos c.$

\textbf{Necessary:} Show that the zero is \emph{unique}.

If $\displaystyle f(x)$ is monotonically increasing (or monotonically
decreasing) for all positive values, then $\displaystyle f(x)$ can only
have one zero in the interval $\displaystyle (0,\infty)$. Hence we
calculate

\begin{align*}\displaystyle
f'(x) = 4^x \ln 4 + 3 \sin x.\end{align*}

$\displaystyle f(x)$ is increasing where $\displaystyle f'(x) > 0$,
i.e., where $\displaystyle 4^x \ln 4 > -3 \sin x$. We consider the
positive real numbers as follows:

\textbf{Case I:} $\displaystyle 0 < x < \pi$. Since
$\displaystyle 4^x \ln 4 > 0$ and $\displaystyle -3 \sin x < 0$ on this
interval, $\displaystyle 4^x \ln 4 > -3 \sin x$ on the interval
$\displaystyle (0, \pi)$.

\textbf{Case II:} $x \geq \pi$. Since
$-3 \leq \displaystyle -3 \sin x \leq 3$ and
$\displaystyle 4^x \ln 4 \geq 4^\pi \ln 4 > 3 \ln e = 3$ on this
interval, $\displaystyle 4^x \ln 4 > -3 \sin x$ on the interval
$\displaystyle [\pi, \infty)$.

It follows that $\displaystyle f'(x) > 0$ on the interval
$\displaystyle (0, \infty)$ and that $\displaystyle f(x)$ is
monotonically increasing on the interval $\displaystyle (0, \infty)$. We
therefore conclude that if there exists a \emph{positive} number
\emph{c} such that $\displaystyle 4^c = 3 \cos c$, this number must be
\emph{unique}.
hints:
Consider the function

\begin{align*}\displaystyle
f(x) = 4^x - 3\cos x\end{align*}

How can you relate the problem to the properties of this function?
Show that $\displaystyle f(x)$ has \emph{at most} one positive zero.

Use \textbf{monotonicity} to show that the \emph{positive} zero of
$\displaystyle f(x)$ must be \emph{unique} (if it exists).

Note that it is \emph{not} necessary to show that a solution
\emph{exists}. (Although this can be done using the \textbf{Intermediate
Value Theorem}.)
